cab.content: (THIS DOCUMENT 13 THE PROPERTY OE HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT)S_E.CJi.J_T CP. 470 (25').Copy No. %J-UCABINETIRISH BOUNDARY COMMISSION. Note by the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs.I find that I unwittingly misled my colleagues this morning when I said that I was tinder the impression that the notes of the Conference with the Irish free State Ministers hod already been sent to them. The correct procedure has as a matter of fact been followed and they hove been submitted to the various Departments conoornod and their observations received. This has also enabled me now to correct the passage with reference to the use of British troop3 as an intermediary in the act of transfer, which in its original version was calculated to give the impression that something much more definite had been agreed to than was actually the oa.ee. The passage (See CP. 467(25) p. 3) will now run as follows r-'"Mr. Amery said that ho understood that Mr. 0'Higgins1' view was that it might bo advisable for British troops toact es intermediaries in tho process of transfer in order to avoid direct contact between the Preo State authorities and tho Northern Ireland police. He assumed that, if It were found expedient to h-ve recourse to this procedure, the same principle would bo observed in the oase of transfersfrom the'Proo St?:te to Northern Ireland".It S o A. odominions Office, S.W.11th November6 1925,
